meta.description: Canonical glossary — field definitions for all governed data sheets

fields.definition: This is the adress of the entity we're signing. Most contracts will have a version of this, sometimes partial. We'll need to get it, break it into its different field, and complete what's missing.
Depending on who's client in the contract, this is either Artist Name or Company Name.
Wouldn't be in the contract
Wouldn't be in the contract
Wouldn't be in the contract

This field represents the type of client we're signing in a contract. On a high level, it's a company vs an individual. In most contracts, it's going to be Artist, Band, Record Label, or Management Company.
This is the date of birth of the individual being signed. It's required for contracts with individuals. Optional for contracts with companies.
This field represents the professional name of the artist or Band. It's required for all contract where we're signing an individual, or contracts signing a company, for 1 or 2 individuals
This field represents the business name of the company we's signing. It's required for all contract where we're signing a business regardless if management or record label.

This field represents the legal name of the artist or the legal name of individuals that form a Band. It's required for all contract where we're signing an individual, or contracts signing a company, for 1 or 2 individuals
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
This is a list of USA states where a company might be legally formed in. We have an "outside USA" option. In addition, not all contract would have this detail in them.
Won't be in the contract
Won't be in the contract
This field is used for contracts with companies. It defines the type of legal entity behind the company. Or the lack of it. It's sadly not available in all contracts.
This is the YouTube link of a client. it's usually in CPA contracts.
This would be the email of the contact. It's usually in the signing block or signing log at the end of the contract
This is the first name of the contact
This is the last name of the contact
This would be the full legal name of the contact.

This field indicates the type of the schedule. And as a result, different fields would be required in the schedule catalog object. Which is a joint table between schedule and catalog. This is an enumerated identifier that tags each Schedule with its specific deal subtype (e.g., “Ownership,” “Termination,”). This single value drives all conditional logic: it tells the system which extra fields, page layouts, and validation rules to load in the Schedule–Catalog junction, ensuring that only data relevant to that deal subtype can be displayed, entered, or processed. This field cannot be empty.

This is the name of the label that the contract is with. It's usually at the top of the contract. Either in the title of the first paragraph. This is not the Artist or a thrid party name. If there is no specified Label, return "None Specified"
This is the number of days where the artist and label promise not to distribute any new music in. It's an optional section in distribution and exclusive licensing contracts.

This is the purcentage of an asset (or assets) that the label acquired as part of a CoPub or Asset Purchase agreement. It's usually in the first part of a contract in the middle of a paragraph. If it is 0, keep this field empty
This is an optional way on how to uncross a new contract with an existing contract or track. To be honest, we've only seen it once so far.

This is an optional percentage that speficy the Administration fee that the label is charging to service a Publishing Administration contract or a Co-Publishing contract. It's usually in the middle of the contract, in a paragraph after the splits section.
A paragraph that explains how and when the advance should be paid along with any clause if linked
fields.example_output: One Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($1,500) (the “Fee”), Fifty Percent (50%) of which shall be deemed a recording cost and Fifty Percent (50%) of which shall be deemed an advance fully recoupable against Producer’s royalty.

fields.definition: This is a dropdown that indicates if the contracts includes anything uncrossed (not cross collaterized). Default is NO. If yes, it depends on what is uncrossed.
options: Asset: Might be a portion of Assets

fields.definition: This is a specific page around the end of the contract. It's usually added if the contract is signed with a Label for a specific client. The field in Salesforce is a checkbox. It's checked if the Inducement Paragraph/page are in the contract, unchecked if not.
This is a manually entered field in SF that indicates the location of the audio file that we bought as part of the related record.
This is a checkbox that indicates if the contracts includes back catalog (sometimes it's called "Existing Masters".

This represents the percentage (commision) the label charges as a fee to re-distribute the back catalog (or existing masters) as a fee on top of the revenue sharing split. it's usually in the middle of the contract around the Revenue sharing paragraph and points.

This is the percentage of revenue sharing for existing masters (back catalog) mentioned in the contract. It's not frequent to have this value on its own. It indicates the client share from the revenue.
This dropdown indicates if we're taking over all of the back catalog of the client, or a portion of it. If back catalog is not mentioned in the contract, the value would be NULL
This is used ONLY when it's a distribution contract with Content monetization as an add-on, AND CMA has it's own term that is different than the distribution one.
This is used ONLY when it's a distribution contract with Content monetization as an add-on, AND CMA has it's own renewal term that is different than the distribution one.
This field indicates the split of the Content Monetization revenue. It indicates the client share from the revenue.
This is used ONLY when it's a distribution contract with Content monetization as an add-on, AND CMA has it's own termination notice that is different than the distribution one.
This is a required field when the contract includes CMA. It defines what type of content monetization is included in the contract.

A collection period is the time during which the label is allowed to collect revenue from the property or asset after the end of the exploitation period. Sometimes it's referred to as "Sell Off Period"
This fields indicates the SUB TYPE of row #39. It's dependant on what's entered there.
This field indicates the type of the contract we have. It's DEDUCTED from the contract content.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) that is in favor of the client for Cover Records. It's usually available in Publishing Contracts or CoPub. Or distro/licensing contracts that include publishing rights. Most of the times, it's highlighted separately. But sometimes, especially in licensing contracts with publishing rights, it's deducted as part of the "Net Profits" split.
This is used ONLY when it's a distribution contract with Channel Partnership as an add-on, AND CPA has it's own term that is different than the distribution one.
This is used ONLY when it's a distribution contract with Channel Partnership as an add-on, AND CPA has it's own renewal term that is different than the distribution one.
This field indicates the split of the Channel Partnership revenue. It indicates the client share from the revenue. We usually have multiple splits in that section. We only track the first one.
This is used ONLY when it's a distribution contract with Channel Partnership as an add-on, AND CPA has it's own termination notice that is different than the distribution one.
This is the most recent date when the contract was signed by either parties. It's usually next to the signatures, or at the end of the document in the signing log.

This is a percentage available in distribution and profit participation contracts. It represents the fee charged for the services of Distribution. It's taken off the top BEFORE the distribution split or profit sharing percentages
This is the name of the label that the contract is with. It's usually at the top of the contract. Either in the title of the first paragraph.
fields.return_format: Format will be complicated here. As long as it's the same in the export. Or if it's different, break into multiple CSVs/Sheets

fields.definition: This is a percentage available in distribution and profit participation contracts. It represents the division of revenue of the label share of an agreement (the other share is called artist share) between the label and another entity. It's usually available in contracts between a company (CMG or one of its subsidiaries) and a company (record label, management company, etc).

This is the date when the contract becomes effective. It's usually on top of the first page in most contracts. If an effective date is not clearly stated, the value gets derived from the most recent signing date.

This field is applicable when "Territories" (See below) is set to "World Excluding Multiples". That value is used as OTHER when the other options don't apply. However, "Excluded Territories" is a text area that should list all the territories exlcuded from the contract when the other options don't apply.
This field's value depends on the commitment from the client. If they're committing to EXCLUSIVELY deliver to us during the term, that's TIME. Otherwise, it's MASTERS

This is part of a distribution or licensing contract. It represents the total number of existing tracks, or assets (back catalog) brought to the label as part of the contract. The full list (or Schedule) is usually availabe around the end after the signature block in a table or list format as a "Schedule"

An exploitation period is the time during which the label is still allowed to use the property or asset for its intended purpose. It usually starts after the initial term, and before the collection period.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) that is in favor of the client for the distribution of front catalog music, or new masters. It's usually available in Distribution Contracts, or licensing contracts. Most of the times, it's highlighted separately as "Digital Phono Record Delivery (i.e., electronic downloads)". But sometimes, especially in licensing contracts, it's deducted as part of the "Net Profits" split.

This is a money amount usually available in purchase agreements or label ventures. It represents the amount of money we're comitting to give away, but we're holding off on doing so until the client does something.
This is a checkbox field that indicates if the contract includes CPA (Channel Partnership) or not.

This field indicates the initial term of the contract.
It should be available in every single contract regardless of the type or format.
This field was created for M&A when we initially onboarded them to Sf in 2023. They had this as a column.
This field was created for M&A when we initially onboarded them to Sf in 2023. They had this as a column.

Available only for Contract Type = Licensing Agreement.

This field will indicate if the licensing is exclusive to us, or non exclusive.

This field indicates if CMG has the rights of first refusal during the term of the agreement or not. We only need to check if there's a paragraph for that in the agreement and return TRUE. Otherwise, return FALSE.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) that is in favor of the client for Mechanical licensing revenue. It's usually available in Publishing Contracts or CoPub. Or distro/licensing contracts that include publishing rights. Most of the times, it's highlighted separately. But sometimes, especially in licensing contracts with publishing rights, it's deducted as part of the "Net Profits" split.

This field indicates if the contract includes a merchandising paragraph. And if it does, are the rights are exclusive to CMG or non-exclusive?
this is usually available in distribution contracts as well as recording and licensing agreements.
This field indicates the split of the merchandizing revenue. It indicates the client share from the revenue.
This fields indicates the status of neighboring rights income in the contracts when it comes to the label share. It is required with 3 different options.

This is mainly used in Licensing agreements. It represents the number of social media posts the client is commited to do to promote the catalog mentioned in the contact. It's usually explicitely defined in the middle of the contracts

This is applicable for Publishing Administration and CoPublishing contracts. It represents the STATE where the contract was notirized by the client. It can be set to NULL if the contract was never notarized.
This indicates the total number of masters committed in a contract. It's usualy a total of tracks available in schedules for distribution and licensing contracts.
This field represents the number of "options" in a contract. The standard is 1 or 2 options.
This is a weird field. It's a number that represents, our of the "Number of New Masters", how many will be distributed as singles?
When a contract includes an option, the option is usually tied to new delivrable by the client. This number represents the total number of masters included in the available options
use this for when there is a additional album in the option ,EP, etc like for regular distro!

This field represents the existance, or lack, of in a distribution or Licensing Contract. It's very rare to find an option in publishing contracts. The option can be a new commitment from the client, or just a buyout.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) that is in favor of the client for OTHER revenue. It's usually available in Publishing Contracts or CoPub. Or distro/licensing contracts that include publishing rights. Most of the times, it's highlighted separately. But sometimes, especially in licensing contracts with publishing rights, it's deducted as part of the "Net Profits" split.

This is a dropdown that indicates if the label is commiting to paying collaborators or not. It's usually a paragraph around the revenue sharing and splits section. In the case of YES, we have 3 versions.
This field represents the frequency in which the label is comitting to pay the client in the contract. It's usually in the Accounting section of a contract, explicitly defined.
This is a number field that represents HOW many days the label has to pay after the end of the cycle. It's explicitly mentioned in most contracts, but some just don't have it.
This field indicates the minimum amount of money the client should have in his balance, to be paid every payment cycle. It should be in every contract, but it isn't in a decent amount.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) that is in favor of the client for Performance Rights revenue. It's usually available in Publishing Contracts or CoPub. Or distro/licensing contracts that include publishing rights. Most of the times, it's highlighted separately. But sometimes, especially in licensing contracts with publishing rights, it's deducted as part of the "Net Profits" split.
This is the split (or revenue sharing) percentage in favor of the client when a distribution or licensing contract includes a pitching rights and procurement clause. It's not always there.
When a distribution or licensing contract includes a pitching procurement clause, the rights are either Exclusive, or not. This field defines that exclusivity

This is applicable to every contract that includes publishing rights (pub admin or copub). Those rights might be on their own, or part of a distribution or licending contract. Every publishing client, or writer, should be registered with a PRO.
This field is used in contract drafting usually to formulate the sentences with the correct gender. In exctraction, it will need to be deducted from reading the contract.
This is required in distribution and licensing contracts. It indicates if the contract has any publishing in it, and what type.
This field represents the number of days in which the label is committing to release an album once all sides agree to it. It's mainly for distribution and licensing contracts
This split exists ONLY in Distribution remix agreements. IT represent the split between the remixer and the artist, on the client side, for a remix.

This field exists in all contract type where we have a renewal. When exlcusivity = Masters, it renews the initial term. When exclusivity=Time, it often renews the exploitation period. 

Renewal means “how long does the term extend automatically after the end of the term?“

This field is available for Pub Admin, CoPub and sync representation contracts. It's also sometimes included in Licensing contracts. It defines any restrictions we might have on high level. None, Sync Licensing, Sample Licensing or both. We have other fields with options that define the exact restrictions for each category.

Retention period is usually the equivalent for Exploitation Period, but for Publishing side of the business. It's an essential part of a publishing admin, coPub or a Distro or Licensing agreement with a publishing component in it. It's usually clearler stated either in the terms section, or in the licensing section.
When a contract has sample licensing restrictions, this field is required to define them.
fields.example_output: Needs Writer Approval, Limits on Fees

fields.definition: This is a merge field with the schedule list (Separate table)
This field is exclusively used in termination documents. It define if it's a termination amendment (client needs to sign) or a termination report (just an FYI)
When a contract has sync licensing restrictions, this field is required to define them.
options: Restrictions on Controversial Figures and Entities

fields.definition: This is available for every single contract where we have synchronization licensing rights. It defines if those rights are exclusive or non exclusive.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) percentage in favor of the client when a contract includes a synchronization licensing rights and. It's there for the vast majority of the contracts. Usually explicitely listed. But in some licensing contracts, it needs to be deduced from the "Net Profits" split.

This is one of the most important fields, and it's required in all of them. It defines WHEN we start counting the initial term of an agreement. If the contract doens't have a renewal term, it's usually X Number of years or post recoup only. If the contract has renewal, it's any of the 3. It's deduced from HOW the term is written.
options: Later of X amount of years AND post recoup

fields.definition: This is the date when a contract was terminated. It's not available in the contract itself, but in the paperwork for its termination.
This is the date when the client notified us that they'd like to terminate a contract.  It's not available in the contract itself, but in the paperwork for its termination.

This is the period before the end of the term (initial or renewal)  usually defined in the terms where the client can give us notice that they're like to terminate. It's basically a minimum notice period for terminating a contract.

This field is exclusively used in termination documents. It define if it's we're terminating contracts by Effective Date (1 offboarding date per contract) or by catalog release date (multiple offboard dates per contract). It' tricky to find it in older termination documents. Usually deduced from the termination language.

This is a dropdown field that explains where the contract is applicable. It's usually referenced as "Territory" or "Territories" in the contract, or implied in a section in the first half. However, it won't be spelled exactly as the options in Salesforce. We'll need some sort of mapping.
This is usually in Purchase Agreements. It defines the type of share we're buying. Is it the label share (or revenue) or the client side (Artist)?
This is a checkbox that defines if the contract (usually distribution or Licensing) includes a clause for holding back releases or not.
This is a multiselect field that defines the changes in an amendment. They're deduced from the contract content that defines what changed in this paperwork, compared ot the one(s) it's referencing.
This field defines if the termination document is terminating a full contract(s), parts of a contract.

This is the split (or revenue sharing) that is in favor of the client for Writer Print revenue. It's usually available in Publishing Contracts or CoPub. Or distro/licensing contracts that include publishing rights. Most of the times, it's not highlighted separately. And sometimes, especially in licensing contracts with publishing rights, it's deducted as part of the "Net Profits" split.
This is the link for the YouTube channel that is included in the contract. It's usually available when the contract includes CPA (Channel Partnership)
This field indicates whether the contract includes physical distribution (CDs, DVDs, Vinyls, etc). It's a required field.

This field indicates the split for physical distribution between the client and the label.
The field is required if the “Physical Distribution?“ is set to YES.
This field is available for any contract combination that includes distribution.

This field indicates the split for physical distribution between the client and the label when the split outside the USA is different that inside USA.

The field is displaued if the “Physical Distribution?“ is set to YES.

This field is available for any contract combination that includes distribution.

A selloff period A sell‑off period is a defined period after termination or expiration of a distribution agreement during which the distributor may continue selling existing stock (e.g., manufactured CDs/vinyl). No new units can be manufactured unless expressly permitted. the purpose is to allow an orderly wind‑down and avoid waste or financial loss.
When a track is part of an album, this would be the album name.
Sometimes, the contract defines the album type: EP, Single, Compilation, etc.
This is the artist name(s) on the track or asset. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the ISRC of a track. This field is meant to catch that.
In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the ISWC of a publishing asset (work). This field is meant to catch that.
In some cases, the contract includes a schedule with actual release dates for each track or asset. This field is meant to catch that.
When a catalog item mentioned in a contract is a remix of another song, this field is meant to capture the artist name of the remixer. The individual who we're signing to remix a track.

A contract can reference different types of catalog. This field is meant to identify if we're talking about a track, album, general asset, sound recording or a compositon (publishing work). It can also be a combination of multiple catalogs with different types in a single contract.
In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the UPC of a track. This field is meant to catch that.

For publishing assets, we usually talk about a Writer and not an artist. In some cases, the contract includes both. The writer name is usually the legal name of a client. Mentioned in the schedule part of a contract.

This is the name of the label that the contract is with. It's usually at the top of the contract. Either in the title of the first paragraph. This is not the Artist or a thrid party name. If there is no specified Label, return "None Specified"
This field represents the amount. It can be the total mentioned in the agreement, or a portion of it if the agreement total is broken into multiple payments.
This is a prepaid, typically recoupable payment made to a party (e.g., an artist or producer) against future earnings or royalties.
This field indicates the currency of the selected financial commitment
This is a number field that defines the total number of days CMG has to pay the payment starting the day it’s triggered.
This is a dropdown field that indicates the trigger for the financial record. It's usually defined right next to the amount
This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
This field is required when the Type is set to Budget. It allows users to specify whether the budget value represents a minimum or maximum amount.
This field is meant for any additional notes around the financial record.
This field links the financial record to its opportunity (Contract)

In some cases, the contract defines who's getting payed for a fee or an advance. In those cases, this field would link to a CONTACT who's the payee defined in the contract. It will need the same fields defined for contacts.

This field indicates the type of the schedule. And as a result, different fields would be required in the schedule catalog object. Which is a joint table between schedule and catalog. This is an enumerated identifier that tags each Schedule with its specific deal subtype (e.g., “Ownership,” “Termination,”). This single value drives all conditional logic: it tells the system which extra fields, page layouts, and validation rules to load in the Schedule–Catalog junction, ensuring that only data relevant to that deal subtype can be displayed, entered, or processed. This field cannot be empty.
This field captures the recoup percentage needed for a client in order to trigger a payment. It's required when the Type is set to Recoup Threshold.

This field captures the streaming threshold value required for financial calculations when the Type is set to Streaming Threshold.

In some contracts, a payment is triggered when a client reaches a certain number of streams (this field) in a certain number of days (row 23)

This field is heavily related to row 24 (Type). It defines on a high level the SUBTYPE of the financial commitment. In combination with row 24, we would know as an example, if it's a marketing advance or marketing budget.

This field specifies the number of days associated with the threshold for payment calculations.

In some contracts, a payment is triggered when a client reaches a certain number of streams (row 21) in a certain number of days (this field)

This field is heavily related to row 22 (SubType). It defines on a high level the TYPE of the financial commitment. In combination with row 22, we would know as an example, if it's a marketing advance or marketing budget.

This field indicates HOW the marketing budget can be spent. Does it need client approval? Client can spend it on their own? mutual approval? or label can spend it on their own? It's not required unless the Type and SubType combination = Marketing Budget

This field indicates if the financial record (budget, advance, fee, etc) is recoupable or not. If the contract mentions that it's recoupable, value is YES. If it mentions that it's not recoupable, value is NO, otherwise, value is N/A
When a track is part of an album, this would be the album name.
This field indicates the type of the schedule. And as a result, different fields would be required in the schedule catalog object. Which is a joint table between schedule and catalog.
In some cases, the contract includes a schedule with actual release dates for each track or asset. This field is meant to catch that.
This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.

This is the percentage of an asset (or assets) that the label acquired as part of a CoPub or Asset Purchase agreement. It's usually in the first part of a contract in the middle of a paragraph. If this is 0, Keep this field empty.
When a track is part of an album, this would be the album name.
Sometimes, the contract defines the album type: EP, Single, Compilation, etc.
This is the artist name(s) on the track or asset. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
Writer name
Track name
This is the % of a composition owned by the human involved in the track/catalog. The human is represented as Asset Owner. It's a contact in Salesforce.
In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the ISRC of a track. This field is meant to catch that.
In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the ISWC of a publishing asset (work). This field is meant to catch that.
This is the % of a sound recording (or Track) owned by the human involved in the track/catalog. The human is represented as Asset Owner. It's a contact in Salesforce.
This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
This is the date when the client notified us that they'd like to terminate a contract.  It's not available in the contract itself, but in the paperwork for its termination.

A contract can reference different types of catalog. This field is meant to identify if we're talking about a track, album, general asset, sound recording or a compositon (publishing work). It can also be a combination of multiple catalogs with different types in a single contract.
In some cases, the back catalog included in the contracts also includes the UPC of a track. This field is meant to catch that.

For publishing assets, we usually talk about a Writer and not an artist. In some cases, the contract includes both. The writer name is the legal name of a client mentioned in the schedule part of a contract. Do not include pka.

In some of the new contracts, an option can be tied to a number or tracks, number of albums, and minimum total number of minutes for that deliverable. This is where we're logging the number of albums tied to that option

In some of the new contracts, an option can be tied to a number or tracks, number of albums, and minimum total number of minutes for that deliverable. This is where we're logging the number of tracks tied to that option
This is the track name or asset name. It's usually specified either in the first page of the contract, or in the schedules section.
For type = Merchandising or Pitching, this field is meant to indicate if the rights are exclusive to us or non-exclusive. The Exclusivity should be listed in the same paragraph as the right itself.

This field is optional and only applies when type=Option. When a contract includes 1 or multiple options, there's usually a clause that indicates the notice period (usually in days) that the label has to notify the client of their intention to trigger/exercise the option. This field is meant to have that value.
For type = Merchandising or Pitching, this field is meant to indicate if the we are taking a fee off the top. If Fee Type!= No Fee, we will need to extract the split.
For type = Merchandising or Pitching, and Fee Type != No Fee, this field will be required. It indicates the revenue sharing model between us and the client. We save the % paid to the client.

In some of the new contracts, an option can be tied to a number or tracks, number of albums, and minimum total number of minutes for that deliverable. This is where we're logging the minimum number of minutes.

This field can be in any type of AddOn. It represents the revenue split between the label and the client for that specific type of addon. It's required for Merchandizing and Pitching. Optional for Options. We save the % paid to the client.

If type = option, this field is required. It defines the genre of the option. Is it an option for additional commitments? (Album or Single) or an option to Buyout the client from their agreement? (Buyout)
When Type = Options, in some contracts, the option extends the contract term by a certain amount of time. This is usually in the paragraph describing the option itself.
This field is required for every single add on. It represents what type of "right" or "option" was added to this contract. Currently, we only support 3, but working on adding others.
This field is required when Type = First Negotiation Rights. It represents the number of days where the client can only negociate with us

This field is required when Type = Matching Rights. It represents the period in days where the Licensee (usually US) agrees to match the Offer the client got from a 3rd party in all material commercial respects.

This field is required when Type = Matching Rights. It refers to the time window in days the Licensor has to consummate the agreement with the third party after the Licensee declines to match the offer
